results.title: Au Coeur de la Vie = in the Heart of Life
results.creator_credit: Robert Enrico, Henry Deutschmeister, Paul de Roubaix and Robert Hossein
results.brief_description:
A dramatization of a short story by Ambrose Bierce set during the American Civil War in which a Confederate citizen stands on the scaffold, about to be hanged, and seems, by a series of miracles, to escape death. See also: The story ‘La Riviere de Hibou’ is available separately on 16mm in the NLA Collection (#0087311). See also: Interview with Robert Enrico about this work in ‘Le Desordre et Apres’ (X000659).

Credits: Producers, Henry Deutschmeister, Robert Hossein, Paul de Roubaix ; director, writer, Robert Enrico ; photography, Jean Boffety ; music, Henri Lanoe.
Cast: Roger Jacquet, Anne Cornaly, Anker Larsen.

results.title: La Nuit de Varennes = the Night of Varennes
results.brief_description:
“Set in June 1791, it concerns the attempted escape from France of Louis XVI and the royal family. In Scola’s fantastical version of history, they are pursued across country by a coach containing not only the lady-in-waiting Comtesse Sophie de la Borde, but also the cultural celebrities of the period: the legendary lover Giacomo Casanova, the English revolutionary Thomas Paine, and the libertarian writer Restif de la Bretonne. ‘La nuit de Varennes’ is hence as much an anthology of eighteenth-century culture as it is a historical account of the Revolution. As ‘Les Cahiers du cinema’ noted at the time, political history is presented as literary history through the eyes of idealised witnesses who - along with the spectator - remain at a safe distance from the proletariat. In a gesture typical of the heritage genre, Scola privileges cultural references of all kinds, and in particular literary forms, whether through direct quotations from contemporary texts or through the emphasis on written communication - messages, maps, articles and decrees - which is the motor behind the plot. The central narrative - the king’s flight from Paris - is moreover framed by the self-conscious device of the puppet show, which first enacts revolutionary events prior to the king’s disapperance, and ultimately closes with his execution.” Reference: Guy Austin. ‘Contemporary French Cinema’. Manchester University Press, 1996.

Credits: Director, Ettore Scola ; writers, Ettore Scola, Sergio Amidei ; photography, Armando Nanuzzi ; music, Armando Trovajoli ; art direction, Dante Ferretti, Pierre Guffroy.
Cast: Jean-Louis Barrault, Marcello Mastroianni, Hanna Schygulla, Harvey Keitel, Jean-Claude Brialy, Andrea Ferreol, Michel Vitold, Laura Betti.

results.title: Les Nouveaux Realistes
results.creator_credit: Adrian Maben, Michele Arnaud and Reiner Moritz
results.brief_description:
Profile of a group of artists trying to bring into their art the reality of urban and industrial landscapes. They include: Yves Klein, Arman, Cesar, Christo, Deschamps, Dufrene, Hains, Tinguely, Nikki de Saint Phalle.

Credits: Producers, Michele Arnaud, Reiner Moritz ; director, Adrian Maben.

results.title: Le Petit Soldat = the Little Soldier
results.creator_credit: Jean-Luc Godard and Georges de Beauregard
results.brief_description:
In Geneva, at the time of the Algerian War, a French secret agent, on a mission to kill a top man in the FLN, finds himself used as a pawn by both sides. Filmed in 1960, Godard’s second feature film was banned by the French government and released, with minor cuts, in 1963 because of its ambivalent attitude to the Algerian War and its reflection of brutality on both sides. Other reasons might have been its matter of fact filming of torture and the treatment of the political crisis as a confusing gangster movie.

Credits: Producer, Georges de beauregard ; director, Jean-Luc Godard ; writer, Jean-Luc Godard ; photography, Raoul Coutard ; music, Maurice Le Roux.
Cast: Michel Subor, Anna Karina, Henri-Jacques Huet, Laszlo Szabo, Mohamed Messoussa.

results.title: Adieu L'ami = So Long, Friend
results.brief_description:
A friendship develops between a French doctor and an American mercenary when both are discharged from the army. Dino and Propp combine forces to help a woman return some stolen bonds before the crime can be discovered. They become trapped for three days in the underground vault system. Propp helps Dino escape before he is captured by the police. The two fall victim to the woman who was used as bait to get them to open the safe. Note: In this version, Charles Bronson’s voice is dubbed in French by American filmmaker John Berry.

Credits: Producer, Serge Silberman ; director, Jean Herman ; writer, Sebastien Japrisot ; photography ; Jean-Jacques Tarbes ; music, Francois de Roubaix.
Cast: Alain Delon, Charles Bronson, Olga Georges-Picot, Bernard Fresson, Brigitte Fossey.

results.title: Un Bon Petit Diable = a Sweet Little Devil
results.creator_credit: Jean-Claude Brialy, Eve Vercel and Robert Nador
results.brief_description:
Charles is an orphan who lives with the cruel Mrs.Leontine MacMiche. Not content at mistreating the child, MacMiche has also stolen his inheritance. Charles’ only allies are Betsy, the maid and Juliette, Charles’ blind cousin.

Credits: Producers, Robert Nador, Eve Vercel ; director, Jean-Claude Brialy ; writers, Jean-Claude Brialy, Didier Decoin ; photography, Jean-Francois Robin ; music, Eric Demarsan.
Cast: Alice Sapritch, Bernadette Lafont, Philippe Clay, Michel Creton, Paul Courtois.

results.title: Ballade Pour Un Chien = Ballad for a Dog
results.brief_description:
Remy Viachet is a lonely old man with money worries. During one of his solitary walks, he finds a stray dog and decides to adopt him. Remy manages to sneak the dog in his appartment unbeknown to the concierge. One day the old man is found dead in his flat, the floor littered with dog food tins intended for an animal that does not seem to exist.

Credits: Director, Gerard Vergez ; writers, Maurice Curry, Gerard Vergez ; photography, Patrice Pouget ; music, Francois Rabbath.
Cast: Charles Vanel, Julien Guiomar, Claude Genia, Colette Regis, Alfred Lenglet.

results.title: Normandie-Niemen
results.creator_credit: Damir Viatich Berejnykh, Jean Dreville and Simon Mariakhine
results.brief_description:
In 1942, 16 French pilots decide to join forces with the Red Army and participate in the Battle of Stalingrad.

Credits: Producer, Simon Mariakhine ; directors, Jean Dreville, Damir Viatich Berejnykh ; writers, Charles Spaak, Elsa Triolet, Constantin Simonov ; photography, Jacques Natteau ; music, Rodeon Stchedrine.
Cast: Marc Cassot, Giani Esposito, Pierre Trabaud, Gerald Buhr, Georges Riviere.

results.title: Agatha et les Lectures Illimitees
results.brief_description:
In a sprawling sea-side mansion, Agatha dialogues with her adored brother. Their impossible love, their common past come back to life as the conversation unfolds. Further viewing: ‘Duras filme’, an account of the making of ‘Agatha …’ - French Embassy Video Collection.

Credits: Director, Marguerite Duras ; writer, Marguerite Duras ; photography, Dominique Le Rigoleur ; music, Johannes Brahms.
Cast: Bulle Ogier, Yann Andrea, Margerite Duras [voice only].

results.title: Escalier C = Staircase C
results.brief_description:
Lafont, a rarefied, egocentric, malicious art critic, and ruthless womanizer, is jolted by a series of encounters and experiences into reconsidering his character. The film’s title refers to the floor of the apartment block where Lafont lives and periodically crosses paths with his neighbours, including a gay artist whose affection he does nothing to discourage. What begins as an intriguing character study degenerates into a superficial and soft-centered film, largely dominated by stereotypes, and of no particular distinguishing features. Reference: Bloomsbury Foreign Film Guide.

Credits: Producer, Marie-Dominique Girodet ; director, Jean-Charles Tacchella ; writers, Elvire Murail, Jean-Charles Tacchella ; photography, Jacques Assuerus ; music, Raymond Alessandrini.
Cast: Robin Renucci, Jean-Pierre Bacri, Jacques Bonaffe, Catherine Leprince, Michel Aumont.
